Award.AwardTitle: An RUI Comprehensive Investigation of Red Dwarf Stars: Ages,Rotation, Magnetic Dynamo Activity and Habitability of Hosted Planets
Award.AbstractNarration:
In his project, Dr. Guinan and collaborators will extend an earlier study on solar-type stars to cooler unevolved stars. The main goals are to measure how stellar rotation slows with time and to explore the relation between ages, rotation rates, and magnetically-driven activity such as chromospheric emission and coronal X-ray flux. The project will study low-mass stars in clusters of known age; if a good age-activity-rotation relation can be found, then the ages of non-cluster stars can be determined.

New satellite experiments are determining a large number of rotation periods and discovering planets around low-mass stars, and it would be important to determine ages for these systems. Determination of the X-ray flux and its evolution will have an impact on whether life would be affected by X-rays on planets in the "habitable zone" of their stars. The project will provide research opportunities for undergraduate students, and will support efforts public in public education and outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Red dwarf stars (i.e. late dwarf K and M-type stars cooler, smaller and less luminous than the Sun) make up over 75 percent of all stars in the our Galaxy. Recent statistical studies of Kepler Mission and ground base data indicate that about 30-40 % of red dwarfs most likely host potentially habitable planets - many of which are Earth-size planets orbiting within the liquid water habitable zones (HZs) of their host stars. For example, recently the nearest star to the Sun  - the red dwarf, Proxima Centauri was discovered to be accompanied by an Earth-size planet located in the middle of the star's HZ.

The primary science goals of this program are to determine the physical properties of red dwarfs that relate to age, rotation, magnetic activity and corresponding coronal X-ray and Ultraviolet chromospheric emissions as well as flares. We found and developed relations among stellar rotation - Age - and Magnetic activity for these stars. In particular we developed relations that return and relate X-ray and UV fluxes of red dwarfs as a function of stellar age. These relations are important for studying the effects of this high energy radiation on the atmospheres of planets hosted by these stars. X-rays and ultraviolet emission can have significant effects on planetary atmospheres in some cases, if strong enough, drastically reducing or eliminating water inventories and also altering the photochemistry of their atmospheres. 

This program returns astrophysically important information about magnetic dynamos & activity, coronal X-ray and chromospheric ultraviolet emissions as well as angular momentum loss of low mass red dwarf stars. From the relations developed in this study, the ages of red dwarfs and their hosted planets can be determined with precisions of better than 20%. The results from this program have recently been applied to study the possibilities for water, and thus life, on the Earth-size exoplanet (Proxima b) hosted by the nearest star-- the red dwarf star Proxima Centauri. We found that in spite of the high levels of X-ray and UV radiation received by the planet from its nearby host star, that there are pathways for the presence of liquid water and potential life on this nearby planet.(see Ribas et al. 2016 Astronomy & Astrophysics, 596,111). We have carried similar studies for other nearby red dwarfs to investigate their suitability for life.

Results from this program have been been published in journals, conference proceedings  and as posters presentations as well as talks at STEM and IAU sponsored education and outreach venues. Results and related materials also have been placed on our website for the Living with a Red Dwarf program at: (http://astronomy.villanova.edu/lward/). In addition to research results, data sets, down loadable power point presentations and posters have also been included on this website.

As an NSF Research at Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) program,the project provided valuable education and research experiences and training for students. During the five years of this RUI program fifteen undergraduate students participated, along with two graduate students and two post-doctorate students. Most of these students presented their results at the meetings of the American Astronomical Society or at other science conferences.
